title: The Archers catch-up: Joe Grundy's brother Alf in shock return
text:
We are taking bets on how long it will be before the One For Joe collection fund at The Bull vanishes

Alf Grundy’s back and he wants you to buy him a pint.

Yes, Joe Grundy’s death has brought with it more than one downside – the main one being his good-for-nothing son Alf.

Not seen since he relieved the church of its collection money and bolted, he rolled up on Friday with a car full of plastic bin liners and the immortal words, ‘I see you’ve got the beers in’.

He managed to drive both Will and Ed out of the family home within the first few minutes – and Clarrielove is already wondering how she’s going to cope with him for three more weeks.

Yes, the funeral is three WEEKS away. That’s a long time to keep the body fresh, but plenty of time for Alf to get his feet under the table and really cause some trouble.

Toby had better keep an eye on that One For Joe wake collection at The Bull – our money’s on that being the first thing to go, if it’s not nailed down.

The second thing to go will be Alf himself.

Talking of things that have gone missing, Peggy’s beside herself after Hilda goes missing during an unwanted visit from Joy Horville. As Joy invites herself in for a cup of tea and bends Peggy’s ear over Rochelle’s latest news, Hilda takes the only way out – she bolts out, not to be seen again.

Tony’s searching the garden, Josh has put posts out on social media and there are posters around Ambridge – but Hilda is not coming back.

Peggy can’t help but blame Joy for driving Hilda away and is full of nothing but venom for the garrulous do-gooder but Pat is sympathetic – she thinks Joy’s just lonely.

Let’s see how she feels about it when she’s had her own Rochelle-themed monologue.

IS 6 MONTHS TOO QUICK FOR SOMEONE WHO IS DEPRESSED TO COME OFF THEIR MEDS? Elizabeth has quit counselling – she went for her last session and has come off her anti-depressants. The storyline has attracted some criticism for being unrealistic – some comments on social media have said that it’s too fast and gives those suffering ‘real mental illness’ false hope. Experts have joined the conversation to say that actually, 6 months on anti-depressants is very normal, as long as the patient believes it is enough, and particularly if the episode of depression was caused or triggered by a set of events that have been fixed or addressed adequately. In Elizabeth’s case, the depression was triggered by a series of life events – primarily, Freddie going to jail, then exacerbated by Lily going off to uni with Russ and with the backdrop of long unresolved grief around the death of husband Nigel. With Freddie and Lily back and doing well and therapy for anxiety and depression also addressing her bereavement and the anger, guilt and loss she felt around that, she was in a good place for the medication to give her brain chemistry the reboot it needed while talking therapy and a restructuring of her work and home life gave her the support required to give her confidence, stability and the feeling she could cope again with life’s demands. In those circumstances, it is perfectly reasonable to hope that Elizabeth should feel prepared to taper her meds after 6 months. She has a support network in place and if she experiences a relapse or even wobbles, she knows where to go.
